tasks.description: Initialize mapping framework (e.g., Leaflet, Mapbox) and set up base map layers.
Retrieve destination dataset from a reliable source (API or static JSON) containing coordinates, names, categories, and descriptive metadata.
Categorize destinations into predefined groups (cities, beaches, national parks, cultural sites) for filtering and display purposes.
Render map markers for each destination, applying category-specific icons or colors.
Implement marker clustering to maintain map readability at various zoom levels.
Create interactive popups or side panels that display destination details when a marker is clicked.
Build a filtering UI that lets users toggle categories and adjust map view accordingly.
Add search functionality to locate destinations by name or keyword.
Ensure responsive design so the map and controls work smoothly on desktop and mobile devices.
Optimize performance (lazy loading, caching) and handle edge cases such as missing data or API failures.
Integrate with a general news API (e.g., NewsAPI.org) to fetch the latest articles from selected high‑quality newspapers such as The Guardian and The New York Times.
Integrate with a location‑based event or news API (e.g., Eventful or a custom geo‑news service) to obtain geographic coordinates and timestamps for news events worldwide.
Normalize and store fetched articles and event data in a relational or document database, including metadata such as source, publication date, and geolocation.
Implement a hotspot detection algorithm that aggregates article counts per geographic region (e.g., city or grid cell) over a sliding time window to identify breaking news clusters.
Expose a RESTful API endpoint that returns a list of current hotspots with associated metadata (e.g., intensity score, dominant news source).
Expose a RESTful API endpoint that returns articles filtered by hotspot, source, or keyword, supporting pagination and sorting.
Implement caching (e.g., Redis) for hotspot and article queries to reduce latency and external API calls.
Set up authentication and rate limiting for the public API to manage usage and protect against abuse.
Create a front‑end dashboard (or provide API documentation) that visualizes hotspots on a map and lists related articles.
Monitor system health and log errors, ensuring high availability and timely updates of news data.
Initialize Google Maps and set up base map layers.
Fetch ocean data from Marinexplore.org API endpoints.
Parse and transform the retrieved data into GeoJSON or other map‑compatible formats.
Overlay ocean statistics layers (temperature, salinity, currents, etc.) onto the map.
Implement user interaction handlers (zoom, pan, click to display pop‑ups with detailed stats).
Provide UI controls for filtering data by type, time range, or geographic region.
Generate shareable links or snapshots of the current map view.
Handle loading states, errors, and data caching.
Optimize performance for large datasets (clustering, tile layers, lazy loading).
Ensure responsive design for desktop and mobile devices.
Gather campus building data (names, addresses, coordinates, and relevant metadata) from a reliable source such as the university’s GIS portal or a public dataset.
Set up a Google Maps JavaScript API integration, including API key management and map initialization centered on the University of Michigan campus.
Plot building markers on the map using the retrieved coordinates, ensuring markers are styled appropriately for campus context.
Implement a search interface (e.g., an autocomplete search box) that queries the building dataset and highlights the selected building on the map.
Create info windows or side panels that display building details (name, address, description) when a marker is clicked or a search result is selected.
Add user interaction features such as marker clustering for dense areas, zoom controls, and responsive layout for mobile devices.
Optimize performance by lazy‑loading markers, debouncing search input, and caching map tiles where possible.
Test the mashup across browsers and devices, ensuring accessibility compliance and handling edge cases (e.g., buildings without coordinates).
Set up the Google Maps JavaScript API with a valid API key and create a responsive map container on the webpage.
Define and load the Vinexpo 2013 facility data (e.g., JSON or GeoJSON) including coordinates, names, descriptions, and categories.
Render facility markers on the map, using custom icons to represent different types of venues (booths, restrooms, information desks, etc.).
Implement info windows that display detailed information when a marker is clicked, including images, schedules, and contact details.
Add a search and filter UI that allows users to find facilities by name, category, or keyword, updating the map view accordingly.
Provide navigation functionality (e.g., directions or step-by-step indoor routing) from the user’s current location or a selected start point to a chosen facility.
Ensure the application is mobile‑friendly, with touch interactions, responsive layout, and optimized loading times.
Implement accessibility features such as ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, and screen‑reader support for map interactions.
Collect raw traffic data from multiple sources (Google Analytics, server logs, third‑party traffic providers) and ingest it into the system.
Normalize and store the ingested data in a scalable database, ensuring consistency and time‑zone alignment.
Compute key traffic metrics (sessions, pageviews, bounce rate, average session duration, traffic sources) for each website.
Apply the valuation algorithm that uses traffic, engagement, and market benchmarks to estimate the website’s monetary value.
Generate interactive dashboards that visualize traffic trends, valuation changes, and key performance indicators for users.
Provide API endpoints for external applications to retrieve traffic data, valuation results, and historical reports.
Implement user authentication, role‑based access control, and account management for webmasters and site owners.
Set up automated notifications (email, SMS, in‑app) to alert users about significant traffic spikes or valuation changes.
Enable data export functionality (CSV, PDF, JSON) for offline analysis and reporting.
Monitor system performance, log errors, and perform regular backups to ensure reliability and data integrity.
Authenticate the user with Twitter OAuth and obtain an access token.
Retrieve the authenticated user’s list of friends (following).
For each friend, request their most recent tweets, limiting the response to ten tweets.
Aggregate the tweets from all friends into a structured format (e.g., JSON array).
Implement error handling for API failures, rate limiting, and missing data.
Design and render the UI component that displays ten tweets per friend, including pagination or lazy loading if necessary.
Cache results to reduce API calls and improve performance.
Provide a refresh mechanism to update the displayed tweets.
Integrate with Twitter API to fetch tweets based on search queries and timezone data.
Render an interactive 3D Earth globe using SVG/Canvas, overlaying timezone boundaries.
Implement mouse wheel event handling to rotate the globe smoothly.
Add click event listeners on timezone regions to display a tweet window with relevant tweets.
Ensure graceful degradation for browsers lacking full SVG support (e.g., fallback to static images).
Optimize performance for mobile devices, particularly iPad, ensuring touch interactions work.
Provide responsive layout and styling for various screen sizes and orientations.
Implement browser compatibility checks and polyfills for IE9 and older browsers.
Add accessibility features (ARIA labels, keyboard navigation).
Set up error handling and loading states for API requests and globe rendering.
Accept and validate the place input from the user.
Query the Google Weather API for the forecast of the specified place.
Parse and extract the relevant forecast information (e.g., temperature, conditions).
Format the extracted data into a tweet‑ready string.
Authenticate with the Twitter API using OAuth.
Post the formatted tweet to the @MalvaWeather account.
Handle errors and implement retry logic for API failures.
Log all operations for monitoring and debugging.
Schedule periodic updates to post forecasts automatically (optional).
Implement user authentication and profile management, including sign‑up, login, and profile editing.
Integrate a mapping service (e.g., Google Maps, Mapbox) to display maps and allow users to place and edit location markers.
Create APIs for adding, updating, and deleting favorite spot markers, storing location data and associated metadata.
Develop friend network functionality: friend requests, accept/decline, and friend list retrieval.
Implement sharing mechanisms so users can share markers with friends, including privacy settings per marker.
Integrate event discovery by connecting to music event APIs (e.g., Songkick, Bandsintown) to fetch nearby gigs of favorite artists.
Build notification services (push/email) to alert users when friends share new spots or when nearby gigs are announced.
Set up data storage (database schema) for users, markers, friendships, and event data, ensuring efficient geospatial queries.
Implement geofencing and proximity alerts to notify users when they are near a shared spot or an upcoming gig.
Add analytics endpoints to track usage metrics, popular spots, and event engagement.
Enforce security and privacy controls, including data encryption, access tokens, and compliance with privacy regulations.
Collect recipient contact information (phone number or email) from the sender.
Resolve the recipient’s address using a lookup API such as Twilio Lookup or Google Maps Geocoding.
Identify and rank nearby florist partners via a florist API or internal database.
Present florist options and floral arrangements to the sender for selection.
Process payment securely through a payment gateway (e.g., Stripe, PayPal).
Place the order with the chosen florist using their API.
Schedule the delivery time and confirm with the florist.
Send notifications (email/SMS) to the sender and recipient about the order and delivery details.
Track delivery status and update the sender in real time.
Handle cancellations, returns, or complaints.
Ensure data privacy and regulatory compliance (GDPR, CCPA).
Log transactions and generate analytics for service improvement.
Initialize and load the Google Maps JavaScript API, creating a map container in the main view.
Render the right‑hand side UI box that lists the current set of four places.
Implement selection handling: when a user clicks a place in the list, geocode the place name to latitude/longitude.
Place a marker on the map at the geocoded coordinates and center the map view on that marker.
Add a 'Next' button that, when clicked, fetches the next four places and updates the list UI.
Maintain pagination state (current page index, total pages) and update the UI and map accordingly.
Provide optional drawing functionality (e.g., drawing markers or shapes) on the map for user interaction.
Implement error handling for geocoding failures, API errors, and UI edge cases.
Authenticate with Yelp API using OAuth 2.0 and obtain an access token.
Map each local business on the site to its corresponding Yelp business ID via search or stored mapping.
Retrieve business details and reviews from Yelp, handling pagination and rate limits.
Cache retrieved reviews locally to reduce API calls and improve performance.
Render reviews on the local business pages, including ratings, text, photos, and timestamps.
Implement error handling and logging for API failures, missing data, or rate‑limit exceedances.
Schedule periodic refreshes of cached reviews to keep content up‑to‑date.
Provide an admin interface for site owners to configure Yelp integration settings (API key, refresh interval, display options).
Implement secure user authentication, registration, and profile management, including OAuth and social login options.
Provide a robust data upload interface with support for large files, resumable uploads, and integration with cloud storage backends.
Implement version control for uploaded files, maintaining a history of changes, allowing rollbacks, and displaying diffs.
Enable granular sharing permissions (public, private, group-based) and secure link generation for data access.
Create a social feed that displays recent uploads, shares, and activity from followed users or groups.
Add collaboration features such as comments, annotations, and real-time editing notifications.
Implement search across datasets, metadata, tags, and user-generated content with filtering options.
Provide real-time notifications and email alerts for new shares, comments, and version updates.
Expose a RESTful API for programmatic access to data, sharing, and analytics, with proper authentication.
Collect and display analytics on data usage, sharing patterns, and user engagement for administrators.
Authenticate with Dribbble API and fetch three random shots.
Parse the API response to extract image URLs and shot links.
Render the three images in the UI with proper styling.
Implement a refresh button that triggers a new API request and updates the images.
Wrap each image in a link that opens the Dribbble shot page in a new tab.
Handle API errors and display fallback UI or error messages.
Use Google Maps Geocoding API to convert a UK location name into latitude and longitude coordinates.
Call a weather API (e.g., OpenWeatherMap, WeatherAPI) with the obtained coordinates to retrieve a 5‑day forecast.
Parse the forecast data and format it into a readable summary (date, temperature range, conditions) for display.
Implement error handling for invalid locations, API failures, and rate‑limit issues, providing user feedback.
Generate QR code from user-provided text, URL, or media link, supporting error correction and size options.
Provide API to customize QR code appearance (color, shape, embedded logo).
Offer apparel templates and allow placement of QR code on selected garment area.
Render high-resolution preview of final design for user confirmation.
Handle order submission, payment processing, and confirmation.
Coordinate with printing service to produce QR-coded apparel.
Manage inventory of apparel stock and track availability.
Provide order tracking and fulfillment status updates to customers.
Design and implement a debounced search input component that triggers API calls as the user types.
Integrate with Amazon Product Advertising API to fetch product data (title, description, price, image, ASIN).
Parse and format the API response to extract necessary fields for display.
Implement client‑side caching of recent search queries to reduce API calls and improve response time.
Handle pagination and infinite scroll to allow browsing of full catalog results beyond the initial suggestions.
Implement error handling, retry logic, and respect Amazon’s rate‑limiting policies.
Build a responsive UI to display product suggestions with images, titles, short descriptions, and price details.
Optimize performance: use memoization, lazy loading of images, and efficient state management.
Set up authentication and secure storage of Amazon API credentials.
Write unit and integration tests for search logic, API integration, and UI components.
Deploy the service to a scalable hosting environment with monitoring and logging.
Authenticate with the Australia Post API and obtain an access token.
Retrieve tracking data for a given parcel number via the Australia Post API.
Parse the tracking events to identify the most recent status and extract latitude/longitude if available.
Convert the extracted location into a format suitable for Google Maps (e.g., GeoJSON).
Integrate with the Google Maps JavaScript API to plot the parcel’s current location and optionally its route history.
Build a user interface that accepts a parcel number, triggers the tracking workflow, and displays the map.
Implement error handling and user feedback for cases such as invalid tracking numbers or API failures.
Authenticate with Canada Post API using the provided API key or OAuth credentials.
Retrieve tracking data for a given parcel number via the Canada Post tracking endpoint.
Parse the tracking response to extract status updates, timestamps, and geographic coordinates.
Normalize coordinate data to latitude/longitude format compatible with Google Maps.
Render a Google Map centered on the parcel’s latest location and plot markers for each tracking event.
Implement real‑time or on‑demand map updates when new tracking data is fetched.
Handle API errors, missing data, and edge cases gracefully with user‑friendly messages.
Cache recent tracking results to reduce API calls and improve response time.
Secure API keys, user data, and map interactions using HTTPS and proper authentication mechanisms.
Deploy the service as a web application or integrate it into an existing platform, ensuring scalability and maintainability.
Authenticate the user and obtain their current latitude and longitude.
Query the Twitter API for recent tweets that include geolocation data within a configurable radius of the user’s location.
Query the Foursquare API for recent check‑ins or posts that are tagged with a location near the user.
Query the geosay API for local posts or comments that are associated with nearby venues or coordinates.
Normalize the data from all sources into a unified schema (source, content, timestamp, latitude, longitude).
Calculate the precise distance (in metres) from each post to the user’s current location using the haversine formula.
Sort the aggregated posts by ascending distance to provide the nearest results first.
Format the sorted results for client consumption, including source, content snippet, distance, and timestamp.
Implement rate‑limit handling and retry logic for each external API to ensure reliability.
Cache recent query results to reduce API calls and improve response times.
Expose a RESTful endpoint that clients can call to retrieve the aggregated, distance‑sorted data.
Enforce security and privacy best practices, including OAuth token handling and GDPR compliance for user data.
Log service metrics and monitor performance to detect and resolve bottlenecks.
Authenticate with Twitter API using OAuth 1.0a or OAuth 2.0 and obtain necessary permissions for user lookup and follow actions.
Determine the user's current geographic location via IP geolocation or device GPS.
Collect search parameters: keywords for bio, location radius, and optional filters.
Query Twitter API's user search endpoint to retrieve users whose location matches the radius and bio contains specified keywords.
Filter and deduplicate the search results, ensuring compliance with Twitter's policies.
Display the filtered list to the user with options to select or auto-select for bulk follow.
Execute bulk follow requests, respecting Twitter's rate limits and handling failures.
Log follow actions and provide feedback to the user.
Implement error handling for API failures, rate limiting, and permission issues.
Provide a user interface (web or mobile) for input, display, and control of the bulk follow process.
Retrieve hurricane track and advisory data from NOAA/NHC APIs or datasets covering 1950 to present.
Parse and normalize the raw data into a unified format (e.g., GeoJSON with timestamps and advisory details).
Store the processed data in a client‑side cache or server‑side database for efficient retrieval.
Implement the map viewer using a mapping library (Leaflet, Mapbox GL, or Google Maps) to plot hurricane tracks and current positions.
Implement the timeline viewer using a timeline library (D3.js, vis.js, or a custom component) to display advisories over time.
Synchronize interactions between the map and timeline: hovering or clicking a storm on one viewer highlights it on the other.
Add UI controls for filtering by year, storm name, category, and advisory type.
Ensure responsive design so the application works well on desktops, tablets, and smartphones.
Implement accessibility features: ARIA labels, keyboard navigation, and screen‑reader support.
Optimize performance for large datasets using techniques such as clustering, lazy loading, and WebGL rendering.
Deploy the application to a hosting platform and set up monitoring and analytics.
Retrieve the list of all bus routes operating in Darwin.
Fetch the timetable for a selected bus route.
Obtain real‑time bus position data for all routes.
Retrieve current traffic conditions for the Darwin area.
Acquire StreetView images for a given bus stop location.
Aggregate bus stop metadata (name, coordinates, served routes).
Generate a timeline view of upcoming arrivals at a selected stop.
Render an interactive map displaying routes, stops, and live bus positions.
Implement caching and data freshness policies to minimize API calls.
Handle authentication, rate limiting, and error recovery for all external APIs.
Compile a comprehensive database of the 7,000 Danish cities and places, including names, coordinates, and administrative identifiers.
Integrate a mapping API (e.g., OpenStreetMap or Google Maps) to render interactive maps for each location.
Aggregate local information from public datasets and third‑party services (business listings, tourism sites, weather, etc.) and associate it with each city/place.
Implement search, filtering, and geospatial query capabilities to allow users to find cities or nearby points of interest.
Design caching and data‑refresh mechanisms to keep the local information up‑to‑date while minimizing API calls.
Expose a RESTful API layer that delivers map tiles, location metadata, and local info to client applications.
Detect the current page context and extract a unique object identifier (URL or resource ID).
Construct and send an authenticated request to Glue’s API to fetch social content related to the identified object.
Parse the API response, extracting comments, user information, timestamps, and any other relevant data.
Render an overlay UI within the browser to display the fetched comments and related information.
Provide user controls within the overlay (close, refresh, navigate to full Glue discussion).
Handle errors and edge cases gracefully, displaying fallback messages when necessary.
Ensure cross‑browser compatibility and package the functionality as a bookmarklet.
Implement optional caching or rate‑limiting to respect Glue’s API usage policies.
Provide basic configuration options (e.g., number of comments to display, UI theme).
Collect flight availability and pricing data from multiple travel agency APIs.
Collect hotel availability and pricing data from multiple travel agency APIs.
Collect airline ticket deals and special offers from partner agencies.
Normalize and transform raw API responses into a unified internal data model.
Aggregate flight, hotel, and ticket data into combined trip packages.
Compare prices across agencies for each trip package and identify the best deals.
Sort and rank aggregated results by price, duration, user ratings, and other criteria.
Implement filtering and sorting options for end‑users (price range, airline preference, hotel star rating, etc.).
Cache frequently requested data to reduce API calls and improve response times.
Manage API authentication, key rotation, and secure storage of credentials.
Handle API rate limits, retries, and graceful degradation in case of service outages.
Render the comparison results in a user‑friendly web or mobile interface.
Log requests, errors, and performance metrics for monitoring and analytics.
Ensure compliance with data privacy regulations (GDPR, CCPA) and secure user data handling.
Implement address validation and geocoding to convert user‑supplied addresses into latitude/longitude coordinates.
Develop distance calculation logic to compute straight‑line or road distance between two coordinates.
Create travel time estimation based on mode of transport and real‑time traffic data.
Generate detailed route information, including waypoints, alternative routes, and step‑by‑step directions.
Expose API endpoints for trip planners to retrieve distance, time, and route data.
Implement mileage reimbursement calculation using standard mileage rates to compute reimbursement amounts.
Set up API authentication, authorization, and rate limiting to secure the service.
Add caching mechanisms for frequent queries to improve performance and reduce external API calls.
Provide robust error handling and fallback strategies for invalid inputs or external service failures.
Create comprehensive documentation and client SDKs to facilitate developer integration.
Authenticate with SeaRates API and securely store credentials.
Fetch real‑time shipment status and location data from SeaRates.
Process, normalize, and persist shipment data for quick access.
Render an interactive map showing current container positions.
Implement real‑time update mechanism (WebSocket or long polling) to refresh map data.
Provide alerts and notifications for status changes or delays.
Display historical routes, ETA calculations, and performance metrics.
Integrate the tracking service with freight forwarder workflows and export data to other systems.
Retrieve real‑time bus location and status data from the CTA API.
Parse and map the bus route, stops, and schedule information.
Render a user interface that displays route progress, including the current bus position and upcoming stops.
Allow users to select a specific stop and set an alarm for that stop.
Continuously monitor the bus’s proximity to the selected stop and determine when it arrives.
Trigger a desktop pop‑up notification when the bus reaches the selected stop.
Implement error handling, API rate‑limit management, and data caching to ensure reliability.
Determine the user's geographic location using IP geolocation or browser geolocation APIs.
Query a movie database API to retrieve theaters within a specified radius of the user's location.
For each retrieved theater, request the current day's showtimes, including movie titles, start times, and available formats.
Aggregate and format the showtime data for display, ensuring consistent time zones and sorting by theater or time.
Build a user interface that lists theaters and their showtimes, optionally providing filtering by movie title, date, or format, and optionally integrating a map view.
Implement error handling, caching, and API key management to ensure reliability and performance.
Set up a Google App Engine project and configure the runtime environment.
Implement FriendFeed OAuth authentication to obtain user access tokens.
Retrieve the authenticated user's FriendFeed feed via the FriendFeed API.
Parse feed items, extracting titles, timestamps, and linked URLs.
Design and render the left frame UI to display the list of feed items.
Design and render the right frame UI to display the linked website content.
Implement AJAX polling to auto‑refresh the feed without full page reloads.
Cache feed data and parsed results to minimize API calls and improve performance.
Handle API errors, rate limits, and authentication failures gracefully.
Deploy the application to Google App Engine and perform end‑to‑end testing.
Identify and collect street art data from community sources such as OpenStreetMap, local art directories, and user‑contributed photo platforms.
Normalize and geocode addresses or place names to obtain latitude and longitude coordinates for each street art entry.
Set up the Google Maps JavaScript API, including obtaining and securely storing the API key.
Create the map view and add markers for each street art location using the geocoded coordinates.
Implement marker clustering to manage dense clusters of street art in popular neighborhoods.
Add info windows to markers that display the street art title, artist, image, and brief description.
Provide a search and filter UI allowing users to filter by neighborhood, art style, or artist name.
Integrate Google Street View to offer an immersive view of the street art location when a marker is clicked.
Implement API key management, usage monitoring, and fallback strategies to handle quota limits.
Optimize performance through data caching, lazy loading of images, and efficient rendering of map elements.
Capture or detect the user's current location or allow manual location input.
Initialize and render a Google Map centered on the selected location.
Query the Google Places API for local search results relevant to the location.
Query the Yahoo Local Search API for local search results relevant to the location.
Merge and deduplicate results from both APIs into a single dataset.
Display aggregated results as markers on the map and/or in a side panel.
Update the map and results automatically when the location changes.
Manage API keys, authentication, and rate‑limit handling for both Google and Yahoo services.
Implement error handling and fallback mechanisms for failed API calls.
Provide a responsive UI for selecting locations, viewing details, and filtering results.
Authenticate with Amazon Product Advertising API using the provided access key, secret key, and associate tag.
Accept user input for gift categories, keywords, price range, and other preferences.
Construct and send a SearchItems request to Amazon to retrieve products matching the user criteria.
Filter the search results to highlight items suitable as gifts (e.g., based on category, ratings, or gift‑specific tags).
Retrieve detailed product information (title, image, price, availability, reviews) for each filtered item.
Present the curated list of gift items to the user in a user‑friendly interface.
Provide options to add selected items to a cart or proceed to purchase via Amazon’s checkout flow.
Implement user authentication and profile management to allow users to register, log in, and manage their account settings.
Integrate with a book data provider (e.g., Google Books API) to enable searching and retrieving book metadata.
Create backend endpoints for book list CRUD operations: create, read, update, delete lists.
Implement functionality to add and remove books from a user's list, ensuring proper validation and persistence.
Develop sharing mechanisms, including public/private list settings and link generation for sharing with others.
Build the frontend UI components for viewing lists, displaying book details, and interacting with list items.
Set up notifications or activity feeds to inform users of new additions or shared list updates.
Design and implement data storage solutions (e.g., relational database) to store users, lists, and book associations.
Ensure secure API endpoints with proper authentication tokens and input validation.
Create responsive UI/UX flows for creating a free book list and showcasing the unique user experience when adding books.
Integrate Google Maps JavaScript API to display a global map with support for custom markers and bird’s‑eye imagery.
Design and implement a scalable data ingestion pipeline to import millions of property listings from multiple real‑estate data providers.
Develop a geospatial indexing system (e.g., using PostGIS or Elasticsearch) to enable fast spatial queries and clustering of listings.
Create a backend service to serve property data via RESTful or GraphQL endpoints, including pagination, filtering, and sorting.
Integrate third‑party neighborhood data APIs (crime, schools, demographics) and map them to property locations.
Build a front‑end UI component that overlays property markers on the map and displays a detailed info panel with property details, bird’s‑eye view, and neighborhood analytics.
Implement search and filter functionality (price range, number of bedrooms, school ratings, crime index) with real‑time map updates.
Set up caching layers (e.g., Redis) to reduce latency for frequently accessed listings and neighborhood data.
Ensure compliance with data privacy regulations (GDPR, CCPA) when handling user data and third‑party datasets.
Develop monitoring and logging infrastructure to track API usage, performance metrics, and error rates.
Implement user authentication and session management for both the shopping platform and XMPP.
Retrieve and display the product catalog from the e‑commerce backend.
Implement shopping cart functionality: add, remove, and update item quantities.
Create checkout workflow and integrate with a payment gateway.
Establish an XMPP connection and authenticate the user with the Jabber server.
Integrate a real‑time chat UI into the shopping interface.
Manage buddy list and presence information via XMPP.
Handle sending and receiving chat messages, including offline message storage.
Trigger chat notifications while the user is browsing or in the cart.
Optionally surface product recommendations based on chat context.
Retrieve TriMet MAX line and station data from the TriMet API or a static data feed.
Parse and transform the retrieved data into a GeoJSON or KML format suitable for Google Maps.
Initialize a Google Maps instance centered on Portland and set appropriate zoom and bounds.
Render MAX lines as polylines on the map using the transformed GeoJSON data.
Render station markers on the map, attaching info windows that display station details when clicked.
Implement a UI component that allows users to filter which MAX lines are displayed.
Optimize map performance by clustering nearby station markers and managing overlay layers efficiently.
Implement user authentication, registration, and profile management.
Create and maintain a company database with CRUD operations.
Design and implement the rating system (numeric scores, weighted averages).
Build review submission, editing, and moderation workflows.
Develop tagging infrastructure and tag management UI.
Implement search and filtering by company, rating, tags, and other metadata.
Add social features: likes, comments, following, and sharing options.
Set up notification and alert mechanisms (email, in-app).
Provide analytics dashboards for users and administrators.
Design public APIs and documentation for external integration.
Retrieve Andrew Speaker’s travel itinerary, including departure/arrival dates, ports, and any available GPS coordinates.
Normalize the itinerary data into a sequential list of latitude/longitude points suitable for mapping.
Use the Google Maps JavaScript API to plot the route across the Atlantic, drawing a polyline through the sequence of points.
Add markers for key waypoints (departure, arrival, intermediate stops) and annotate them with relevant information (e.g., port name, date, TB status).
Generate a shareable map link or embed code that can be integrated into a web page or shared with stakeholders.
Integrate a reliable map tile provider that covers Poland, ensuring high-quality tiles and proper attribution.
Implement geocoding and reverse‑geocoding endpoints for Polish addresses, leveraging a dedicated Polish address database or service.
Create a mashup layer that overlays additional Polish data (e.g., weather or traffic) onto the map tiles, delivering a combined visual output.
Geocode city names to latitude/longitude coordinates.
Compute the great-circle distance between two coordinate pairs.
Retrieve a list of notable landmarks for a given city.
Generate a day-long route that sequences landmarks within a feasible travel time and distance.
Expose an API endpoint `/distance` that returns the distance between two cities.
Expose an API endpoint `/day-route` that returns the generated itinerary for a city.
Implement caching for geocoding and landmark queries to improve performance.
Provide comprehensive API documentation and usage examples.
Implement secure user authentication and role-based authorization.
Create user profile management with personal details, avatar, and preferences.
Develop GPS data ingestion pipeline to capture real‑time location data from riders.
Integrate GIS libraries to process routes, calculate distances, elevation profiles, and identify points of interest.
Design and implement a relational/NoSQL database schema for storing users, tracks, GPS points, and metadata.
Embed Google Maps API for interactive map rendering, marker placement, and route visualization.
Build a route planning engine that offers optimal paths, alternative routes, and estimated travel times.
Create a community feed where users can share tracks, comment, like, and follow other riders.
Implement search and filtering capabilities for tracks based on location, length, difficulty, and user ratings.
Develop an administrative dashboard for content moderation, user management, and system monitoring.
Set up analytics to track usage metrics, popular routes, and user engagement.
Integrate a notification system for ride reminders, comments, and community updates.
Acquire the user's current geographic location using the browser's Geolocation API.
Query the backend service for childcare providers within a specified radius, applying filters such as age range, availability, rating, and price.
Normalize and enrich provider data (name, address, coordinates, contact info, services offered) for consistent display.
Render provider markers on Google Maps, using clustering for dense areas and custom icons for different provider types.
Implement interactive info windows that appear on marker click, showing provider details and options to call, message, or view a booking page.
Provide filtering controls (price, rating, services) that update the map in real time and allow users to save preferences or search history.

Extract and normalize metadata (sport type, difficulty, location, tags) from uploaded diagrams.
